newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan premium unmoved by DKB resignation news.
newsitem.headline: Japan premium unmoved by DKB resignation news.

text.p: The Japan premium -- the extra cost Japanese banks pay for raising funds in the Eurodollar interbank market -- was little changed on Friday after news that top officials at Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd (DKB) will resign, traders said on Friday.
DKB said president Katsuhiko Kondo and chairman Tadashi Okuda will step down after a June 27 shareholders' meeting to take responsibility for the bank's involvement in a racketeer scandal.
The premium for one-month Eurodollar deposits was at 2/32 of a point on Friday, unchanged from Thursday, but narrowed from 7/32 on Tuesday when the scandal first hit DKB.
Major U.S. and European banks with better credit ratings than Japanese banks are paying 5-11/16 percent in raising one-month Eurodollar funds.
Some traders said DKB had been active on Tuesday in raising one-month yen funds which it later converted into dollars to ensure the short-term dollar cash liquidity.
But such activities by DKB appeared to have slowed as the premium fell in the following days, they said.
"The scandal will deal a heavy blow to DKB's prestige, but it does not mean any imminent financial instability or massive losses at the bank," said a European bank trader.

Prosecutors raided the headquarters of DKB and the homes of several senior officials earlier this week over suspicions that it funnelled funds to Ryuichi Koike, a racketeer at the centre of payoff scandal involving Nomura Securities Co.
Japan's Commercial Code bans companies from making payments to "sokaiya", racketeers who typically extort money from companies by threatening to disrupt shareholder meetings.
